course.title: Myth in Human Culture
course.subtitle: From Ancient Legends to Modern Storytelling
course.description: This course provides an in-depth study of myths and legends. Topics include the varied sources of myths and their influence on the individual and society within diverse cultural contexts. Upon completion, students should be able to demonstrate a general familiarity with myths and a broad-based understanding of the influence of myths and legends on modern culture.

clos.text: Analyze the structure, function, and significance of myths across diverse cultures
Evaluate how myths reflect and shape cultural values, beliefs, and identities
Apply mythological archetypes and patterns to interpret modern narratives
Create original analysis demonstrating understanding of mythological influence on modern culture

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Pattern Recognition
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Identify recurring themes, archetypes, and structures across mythological traditions

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Cultural Contextualization
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Situate myths within their cultural, historical, and social contexts

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Comparative Analysis
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Compare mythological elements across cultures and time periods

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Symbolic Interpretation
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Decode symbolic meanings and metaphorical content in mythological narratives

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Contemporary Application
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Connect ancient myths to modern storytelling and cultural phenomena

mythologicalThinkingSkills.name: Critical Analysis
mythologicalThinkingSkills.description: Evaluate the function and impact of mythological narratives in society

modules.title: Introduction to Mythology & Creation Myths
inquiryQuestions: What defines a myth, and how do myths differ from other forms of storytelling?
Why do diverse cultures develop similar creation stories despite geographic separation?
How do creation myths establish cultural values and worldviews?

mlos.text: Define mythology and distinguish myths from legends, folktales, and fairy tales
Analyze common patterns in creation myths from different cultures
Evaluate how creation myths reflect cultural values and worldviews

content.title: IC1: What is Mythology?
content.description: Definition of myth, functions of mythology, myth vs. other narrative forms

content.title: IC2: Creation Myths Across Cultures
content.description: Ex nihilo creation, emergence myths, world parent myths, cosmic egg myths

content.title: IC3: Cultural Functions of Mythology
content.description: Social cohesion, moral instruction, explaining natural phenomena, establishing authority

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key mythological terms with their correct definitions. Terms include archetype, cosmogony, theogony, pantheon, and more. You have 2 attempts and 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Mythology Traditions & Figures
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 multiple-choice questions about creation myths from various cultures including Greek, Norse, Egyptian, and Indigenous American traditions. You have 2 attempts and 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Creation Myth Patterns
activities.studentInstructions: Categorize 12 creation myths by type: Ex Nihilo (from nothing), Emergence (from underworld), World Parent (separation), or Cosmic Egg. You have 2 attempts and 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 1 Project Checkpoint: Choosing Your Modern Myth

modules.title: Hero's Journey & Epic Tales
inquiryQuestions: What makes a character a mythological hero versus an ordinary protagonist?
Why does the Hero's Journey pattern appear in stories across all cultures and time periods?
How do cultural values shape the specific challenges and trials heroes face?

mlos.text: Explain Joseph Campbell's Hero's Journey framework and its stages
Analyze how classical heroes from different cultures embody their society's values
Compare heroic journeys across Greek, Norse, Mesopotamian, and other mythological traditions

content.title: IC1: The Hero's Journey Framework
content.description: Campbell's monomyth, departure-initiation-return structure, threshold guardians, mentors

content.title: IC2: Classical Heroes
content.description: Gilgamesh, Odysseus, Beowulf, Rama, characteristics of mythological heroes

content.title: IC3: Cultural Heroic Ideals
content.description: Greek arete, Norse honor, Eastern duty, heroic codes across cultures

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including monomyth, arete, threshold guardian, call to adventure, apotheosis, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Heroes & Their Journeys
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Gilgamesh, Odysseus, Beowulf, and the stages of the Hero's Journey. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Hero's Journey Stages
activities.studentInstructions: Sequence the 12 stages of Campbell's Hero's Journey in correct order and match examples from classical myths. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 1: Heroic Ideals & Portfolio Piece #2

modules.title: Modern Mythology: Star Wars Universe
inquiryQuestions: How does Star Wars consciously recreate the Hero's Journey for modern audiences?
What ancient mythological elements does George Lucas adapt in the Star Wars saga?
How does the Force function as a modern mythological belief system?

mlos.text: Analyze how Star Wars embodies Campbell's Hero's Journey structure
Identify classical mythological archetypes in Star Wars characters and themes
Evaluate how Star Wars creates a modern mythology that resonates with contemporary audiences

content.title: IC1: Luke Skywalker's Hero's Journey
content.description: Call to adventure, mentors (Obi-Wan, Yoda), trials, abyss, transformation, return

content.title: IC2: Mythological Archetypes in Star Wars
content.description: Wise old man (Yoda), shadow (Vader), trickster (Han Solo), maiden (Leia), divine twins

content.title: IC3: The Force as Modern Mythology
content.description: Dualism (light/dark), Eastern philosophy influences, Jedi as mythic warrior-monks

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including archetypes, the Force, threshold guardian, apotheosis, shadow self, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Star Wars Characters & Archetypes
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Star Wars characters, their mythological parallels, and Hero's Journey stages. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Mapping Luke's Journey
activities.studentInstructions: Choose between mapping Luke's journey to Campbell's stages OR categorizing Star Wars elements by mythological tradition. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

activities.title: LA4: Star Wars Mythology Analysis
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze narrative structure data, character archetype patterns, and thematic elements across the Star Wars saga. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 3 Project Checkpoint: Analyzing Your Modern Myth

modules.title: Modern Mythology: Tolkien's Legendarium
inquiryQuestions: How did Tolkien deliberately create a complete mythology for England?
What elements from Norse, Finnish, Celtic, and Christian mythology appear in Middle-earth?
How does The Lord of the Rings function as a modern epic in the classical tradition?

mlos.text: Explain Tolkien's Legendarium as a constructed mythology with creation myth, pantheon, and cosmology
Analyze mythological influences from Norse, Finnish, Celtic, and Christian traditions in Middle-earth
Evaluate how Tolkien's work bridges ancient mythology and modern fantasy literature

content.title: IC1: The Ainulindalë - Tolkien's Creation Myth
content.description: Eru Ilúvatar, Ainur, Music of Creation, Melkor's discord, Valar and Maiar

content.title: IC2: Mythological Influences in Middle-earth
content.description: Norse (dwarves, cursed rings), Finnish (Kalevala), Celtic (elves), Greek (Atlantis/Númenor)

content.title: IC3: Frodo's Quest as Epic Journey
content.description: Fellowship structure, ring as cursed object, themes of sacrifice and mercy

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Ainulindalë, Valar, Legendarium, Andvaranaut, Middle-earth, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Characters & Mythological Parallels
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Middle-earth mythology, characters, and their classical parallels. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Mythological Sources Identification
activities.studentInstructions: Categorize 12 Middle-earth elements by their mythological source: Norse, Finnish, Celtic, Greek, or Christian. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 2: Creating Modern Mythology & Portfolio Piece #4

modules.title: Modern Mythology: Harry Potter & Wizarding World
inquiryQuestions: How does Harry Potter adapt classical hero myths for contemporary young adult audiences?
What mythological creatures and magical traditions does Rowling draw from world mythology?
How does the wizarding world function as a hidden mythological realm alongside ordinary reality?

mlos.text: Analyze Harry Potter's journey using the Hero's Journey framework
Identify mythological creatures, symbols, and traditions from diverse world mythologies in the series
Evaluate how the series addresses themes of death, sacrifice, and immortality common in mythology

content.title: IC1: Harry as the Chosen One
content.description: Prophesied hero, orphan archetype, mentor figures (Dumbledore), trials across seven books

content.title: IC2: Mythological Creatures & Magical Traditions
content.description: Greek (basilisk, centaur), Celtic (banshee), Egyptian (sphinx), alchemical traditions

content.title: IC3: Death, Sacrifice, and the Deathly Hallows
content.description: Tale of Three Brothers, sacrifice as transformative power, Horcruxes and immortality

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including chosen one, Horcrux, basilisk, prophecy, Deathly Hallows, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Characters & Mythological Roles
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Harry Potter characters, magical creatures, and their mythological origins. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Creature Origins Matching
activities.studentInstructions: Match 12 magical creatures from Harry Potter to their mythological tradition of origin (Greek, Celtic, Norse, Egyptian, etc.). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 5 Project Checkpoint: Comparative Mythology Analysis

modules.title: Superhero Mythology & Comic Book Universes
inquiryQuestions: How do superhero origin stories mirror classical divine and heroic myths?
What makes the Marvel and DC universes function as modern pantheons?
How do superheroes address contemporary moral questions through mythological frameworks?

mlos.text: Analyze superhero origin stories as modern versions of divine birth and transformation myths
Compare superhero teams and rivalries to classical pantheon structures and divine conflicts
Evaluate how superhero narratives reflect and shape contemporary cultural values

content.title: IC1: Superhero Origins as Transformation Myths
content.description: Spider-Man (bite), Superman (divine alien), Batman (trauma), X-Men (mutation as difference)

content.title: IC2: Marvel & DC as Modern Pantheons
content.description: Avengers as Olympians, Justice League hierarchy, Thor's actual Norse mythology, god-tier characters

content.title: IC3: Superhero Ethics & Contemporary Values
content.description: Power and responsibility, vigilante justice, Civil War as mythic conflict, diversity and representation

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including origin story, pantheon, alter ego, multiverse, cosmic entity, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Superheroes & Mythological Parallels
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about superheroes, their origins, and parallels to classical mythology. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Superhero-God Comparisons
activities.studentInstructions: Match 12 superheroes to their closest classical mythological parallel based on powers, personality, and role. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

activities.title: LA4: Analyzing Superhero Mythology Impact
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze data on superhero origin patterns, character archetype distribution, and cultural impact across comic book history. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 3: Modern Myths & Cultural Values

modules.title: Mythology in Popular Culture
inquiryQuestions: How do video games, anime, and streaming series adapt mythological narratives?
What role does mythology play in brand storytelling and advertising?
How do internet memes and viral stories function as modern folklore?

mlos.text: Identify mythological elements in diverse media including games, television, and digital culture
Analyze how brands and corporations use mythological storytelling for cultural impact
Evaluate the creation and spread of modern myths through digital and social media

content.title: IC1: Mythology in Video Games & Anime
content.description: God of War, Zelda mythology, Studio Ghibli, anime mythological adaptations

content.title: IC2: Brand Mythology & Corporate Storytelling
content.description: Apple's creation myth, Nike and goddess of victory, mythic archetypes in advertising

content.title: IC3: Digital Folklore & Internet Mythology
content.description: Urban legends, creepypasta, memes as modern myths, viral storytelling

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including brand mythology, digital folklore, transmedia, archetype marketing, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Pop Culture Mythology
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about mythology in games, media, branding, and digital culture. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Mythological Elements Identification
activities.studentInstructions: Categorize 12 popular culture examples by the type of mythology they employ or reference. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 7 Final Portfolio: 'Modern Myth Analysis' Complete Journey

modules.title: Creating Your Own Modern Myth
inquiryQuestions: What essential elements must a story have to function as a modern myth?
How can you consciously incorporate mythological patterns while creating original narratives?
What makes a story resonate across cultures and generations?

mlos.text: Apply mythological structures and archetypes to create original narratives
Synthesize elements from diverse mythological traditions into cohesive new stories
Evaluate the effectiveness of mythological storytelling in contemporary contexts

content.title: IC1: Building Mythological Worlds
content.description: Cosmology, pantheon structure, magic systems, world-building fundamentals

content.title: IC2: Character Archetypes & Development
content.description: Hero variants, mentor figures, shadow antagonists, tricksters, creating memorable characters

content.title: IC3: Thematic Depth & Cultural Resonance
content.description: Universal themes, cultural specificity, moral complexity, contemporary relevance

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including world-building, cosmology, character arc, thematic unity, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: Mythmaking Techniques
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about narrative construction, archetype usage, and effective mythological storytelling. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Story Element Analysis
activities.studentInstructions: Match 12 story elements to their mythological function or archetype category. 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 4: Mythology's Future & Final Reflection
